00038 /** @brief A contiguous block in memory.
00039 * 
00040  * The data block is allocated with malloc(3) and the
00041  * object is placed at the beginning of that allocated memory block.
00042 * /
00043 struct MemoryBlock : public Referenceable {
00044   private:
00045     // Do not allow construction, copying or assignment of this class.
00046     MemoryBlock(MemoryBlock const&) : Referenceable() { }
00047     MemoryBlock& operator=(MemoryBlock const&) { return* this; }
00048 
00049   /** @name Construction and destruction* /
00050   //@{
00051 
00052   protected:
00053     // Except construction by MemoryBlockNode (which derives from this class).
00054     //! Constructor.
00055     MemoryBlock() { }
00056 
00057   public:
00058     /** @brief Operator new.
00059     * 
00060      * Construct object (derived from MemoryBlock) with:
00061      * \code
00062      * Object* obj = new (block_size) Object(params);
00063     * /
00064     void* operator new(size_t object_size, size_t block_size)
00065     {
00066       void* ptr = malloc(object_size + block_size);
00067       AllocTag(reinterpret_cast<char*>(ptr), "MemoryBlockNode (" << object_size << " bytes) + buffer allocation");
00068       return ptr;
00069     }
00070 
00071     //! Operator delete.
00072     void operator delete(void* ptr) { free(ptr); }
00073 
00074   //@}
00075 };
00076 
00077 /** @brief A node in a linked list of memory blocks.
00078 * 
00079  * This class is derived from MemoryBlock.
00080  * The difference is that each node contains a reference to the next node.
00081  * As a result is that the very existence of a node keeps the chain of
00082  * following nodes alive.
00083 * /
00084 struct MemoryBlockNode : public MemoryBlock {
00085   private:
00086     size_t M_valid_bytes;                       //!< Number of valid bytes in this block.
00087     Glib::RefPtr<MemoryBlockNode> M_next;       //!< Reference to the next block, if any.
00088 
00089     //! The offset from the 'this' pointer of this object to the start of the data block.
00090     static size_t const S_data_offset;
00091 
00092   private:
00093     // Constructor. See MemoryBlockNode::create.
00094     MemoryBlockNode(void) : M_valid_bytes(0) { }
00095 
00096   /** @name Creation and destruction* /
00097   //@{
00098 
00099   public:
00100     /** @brief Allocate a new MemoryBlock with room for \a size bytes of data.
00101      * 
00102       * The actual number of bytes allocated are sizeof(MemoryBlockNode) + \a size.
00103      * /
00104     static Glib::RefPtr<MemoryBlockNode> create(size_t size)
00105     {
00106       return Glib::RefPtr<MemoryBlockNode>(new (size) MemoryBlockNode);
00107     }
00108 
00109   //@}
00110 
00111   private:
00112     friend class MemoryBlockList;
00113     // This function may only be called by class MemoryBlockList.
00114 
00115     /** @brief Set how many bytes where just written to \a new_block and append it to the chain.
00116     * 
00117      * This block must be the last node in the chain.
00118     * /
00119     void append(Glib::RefPtr<MemoryBlockNode>& new_block, size_t valid_bytes)
00120     {
00121       new_block->M_valid_bytes = valid_bytes;
00122       M_next.swap(new_block);
00123     }
00124 
00125   public:
00126   /** @name Accessors* /
00127   //@{
00128 
00129     //! Return a pointer to the first data byte.
00130     char* block_begin(void) { return reinterpret_cast<char*>(this) + S_data_offset; }
00131 
00132     //! Return a const pointer to the first data byte.
00133     char const* block_begin(void) const { return reinterpret_cast<char const*>(this) + S_data_offset; }
00134 
00135     //! Return a pointer to one byte past the last valid byte in this block.
00136     char const* block_end(void) const { return reinterpret_cast<char const*>(this) + S_data_offset + M_valid_bytes; }
00137 
00138     //! Return the number of valid bytes in this block.
00139     size_t valid_bytes(void) const { return M_valid_bytes; }
00140 
00141     //! Return true if this is the last block in the chain.
00142     bool is_last_block(void) const { return !M_next; }
00143 
00144     //! Return a reference to the next block.
00145     Glib::RefPtr<MemoryBlockNode> const& next(void) const { return M_next; }
00146 
00147   //@}
00148 };
00149 
00150 struct MutexCondPair {
00151   Glib::Mutex mutex;
00152   Glib::Cond cond;
00153 };

00155 class MemoryBlockList;

00157 /** @brief An immutable MemoryBlockList forward iterator for boost::spirit.
00158 * 
00159  * However, this class is <em>not</em> Default Constructible.
00160 * 
00161  * Also, this class also has no postincrement operator.
00162  * This is a deliberate choice; a good algorithm should use preincrement only for efficiency reasons.
00163 * 
00164  * It is
00165 * 
00166  * - <a href="http://www.sgi.com/tech/stl/Assignable.html">Assignable</a> (copy-constructor and <code>operator=</code>)
00167  * - <a href="http://www.sgi.com/tech/stl/EqualityComparable.html">Equality Comparable</a> (<code>operator==</code> and <code>operator!=</code>)
00168  * - Dereferenceable (<code>operator*</code> which returns an <em>immutable</em> reference)
00169  * - Incrementable (preincrement <code>operator++</code>)
00170 * 
00171  * A forward iterator is essentially an <a href="http://www.sgi.com/tech/stl/InputIterator.html">Input Iterator</a>.
00172  * However, incrementing a forward iterator does not invalidate copies of the old value and it is guaranteed that,
00173  * if i and j are dereferenceable and i == j, then ++i == ++j. As a consequence of these two facts, it is possible
00174  * to pass through the same Forward Iterator twice. In other words, it is possible to use Forward Iterators (unlike
00175  * Input Iterators) in multipass algorithms.
00176 * 
00177  * Of course, the past-the-end iterator is singular, non-dereferencable and non-incrementable.
00178 * /
00179 class MemoryBlockListIterator {
00180   public:
00181   /** @name Required iterator types* /
00182   //@{
00183 
00184     typedef std::input_iterator_tag iterator_category;
00185     typedef char value_type;
00186     typedef ptrdiff_t difference_type;
00187     typedef char const* pointer;
00188     typedef char const& reference;
00189 
00190   //@}
00191 
00192   private:
00193     MemoryBlockList* const M_buffer;                    //!< The linked list of blocks that this iterator belongs to.
00194     Glib::RefPtr<MemoryBlockNode const> M_block;        //!< Reference to block that this iterator points into.
00195     char const* M_ptr;                                  //!< Pointer to the current character inside that block.
00196     char const* M_block_end;                            //!< Cache of pointer to the end of the block (MemoryBlockNode::block_end()).
00197     int M_processed_blocks;                             //!< The number of blocks this iterator consumed.
00198 
00199   public:
00200   /** @name Assignable* /
00201   //@{
00202 
00203     //! Copy-constructor.
00204     MemoryBlockListIterator(MemoryBlockListIterator const& iter) :
00205         M_buffer(iter.M_buffer),
00206         M_block(iter.M_block),
00207         M_ptr(iter.M_ptr),
00208         M_block_end(iter.M_block_end),
00209         M_processed_blocks(iter.M_processed_blocks)
00210         { }
00211 
00212     //! Assignment operator (used for backtracking).
00213     MemoryBlockListIterator& operator=(MemoryBlockListIterator const& iter)
00214         {
00215           assert(M_buffer == iter.M_buffer);
00216           M_block = iter.M_block;
00217           M_ptr = iter.M_ptr;
00218           M_block_end = iter.M_block_end;
00219           M_processed_blocks = iter.M_processed_blocks;
00220         }
00221 
00222   //@}
00223 
00224   /** @name Equality Comparable* /
00225   //@{
00226 
00227     friend bool operator==(MemoryBlockListIterator const& a, MemoryBlockListIterator const& b) { return a.M_ptr == b.M_ptr; }
00228     friend bool operator!=(MemoryBlockListIterator const& a, MemoryBlockListIterator const& b) { return a.M_ptr != b.M_ptr; }
00229 
00230   //@}
00231 
00232   /** @name Dereferenceable* /
00233   //@{
00234 
00235     value_type const& operator*(void) const { return* M_ptr; }
00236 
00237   //@}
00238 
00239   /** @name Incrementable* /
00240   //@{
00241 
00242     //! Pre-increment operator.
00243     // This function is only called from the DatabaseSeekable::read_thread thread.
00244     MemoryBlockListIterator& operator++(void)
00245     {
00246       if (G_UNLIKELY(M_ptr == M_block_end))
00247         advance_to_next_block();
00248       else
00249         ++M_ptr;
00250       return* this;
00251     }
00252 
00253   //@}
00254 
00255     //! Construct the past-the-end iterator.
00256     MemoryBlockListIterator(MemoryBlockList* buffer) : M_buffer(buffer), M_ptr(NULL), M_processed_blocks(0) { }
00257 
00258     //! Make this iterator point to the beginning of \a node.
00259     MemoryBlockListIterator& operator=(Glib::RefPtr<MemoryBlockNode const> const& node)
00260         {
00261           assert(M_buffer);
00262           M_block = node;
00263           M_ptr = node->block_begin();
00264           M_block_end = node->block_end() - 1;
00265           M_processed_blocks = 0;
00266         }
00267 
00268   /** @name Accessors* /
00269   //@{
00270 
00271     int processed_blocks(void) const { return M_processed_blocks; }
00272 
00273     MemoryBlockList* buffer(void) { return M_buffer; }
00274 
00275   //@}
00276 
00277   private:
00278     void advance_to_next_block(void);
00279 };
00280 
00281 /** A linked list of MemoryBlockNode objects.
00282 * 
00283  * The idea of this linked list is as follows:
00284 * 
00285  * A newly created list is entirely empty.
00286  * When the first block is appended, then M_begin is set to point to this first block.
00287 * 
00288  * A different thread should only start to process this block once the
00289  * second block is appended: when
00290 * /
00291 class MemoryBlockList {
00292   public:
00293     typedef MemoryBlockListIterator iterator;
00294     typedef sigc::slot<void> SlotNeedMoreData;
00295 
00296     // The the minimum buffer size in blocks is 4.
00297     // We use 8 because that makes the inner loop use
00298     // a little let overhead related to buffer full checks.
00299     static int const S_max_blocks = 8;
00300 
00301   private:
00302     Glib::RefPtr<MemoryBlockNode> M_last_node;  //!< A pointer to the last node in the list.
00303     iterator M_begin;                           //!< A pointer to the first node in the list. Read/write access by 'DatabaseSeekable::read_thread'.
00304     int M_appended_blocks;                      //!< The number of blocks appended to this list. Read access by 'DatabaseSeekable::read_thread'.
00305     bool M_closed;                              //!< False until the last block was appended and the read_thread is the only thread accessing this buffer.
00306     bool M_buffer_full;                         //!< True while the main thread stops reading new blocks.
00307     Glib::Dispatcher M_need_more_data;          //!< Used to signal the main thread that more data can be appended to the buffer.
00308     SlotNeedMoreData M_slot_need_more_data;     //!< Pass the signal on the calling object.
00309     MutexCondPair M_more_data;                  //!< Used for signaling that more data in the buffer is ready to be processed.
00310 
00311   public:
00312     MemoryBlockList(SlotNeedMoreData const& slot) : M_begin(this), M_appended_blocks(0), M_closed(false), M_buffer_full(false), M_slot_need_more_data(slot)
00313         { M_need_more_data.connect(sigc::mem_fun(*this,& MemoryBlockList::need_more_data_callback)); }
00314 
00315     void append(Glib::RefPtr<MemoryBlockNode>& new_block, size_t valid_bytes)
00316     {
00317       int blocks;
00318       if (G_UNLIKELY(!M_last_node))
00319       {
00320         // If there is no last node, then this is the very first data block
00321         // being appended. In that case the 'read thread' is not running:
00322         // there wasn't any data yet in this buffer. Therefore, no locks
00323         // are necessary.
00324         new_block->M_valid_bytes = valid_bytes;
00325         M_last_node.swap(new_block);
00326         M_begin = M_last_node;
00327         Dout(dc::notice, "Appending FIRST block to the list. Number of blocks is now 1");
00328         assert(M_appended_blocks == 0);
00329         M_appended_blocks = 1;
00330         blocks = 1;
00331       }
00332       else
00333       {
00334         // The read thread is only running if there is more than one
00335         // block available for processing (it won't touch the last
00336         // block). Therefore, appending a new block doesn't need locking.
00337         M_last_node->append(new_block, valid_bytes);
00338         M_last_node = M_last_node->M_next;
00339         // Increment block counter and signal the read thread if we have more than 1 block.
00340         ++M_appended_blocks;
00341         blocks = M_appended_blocks - M_begin.processed_blocks();
00342         Dout(dc::notice, "Appending a new block to the list. Number of unread blocks: " << blocks);
00343         // There should be always at least two blocks in the buffer now.
00344         M_more_data.cond.signal();
00345       }
00346       // Stop reading if there are eight or more blocks already buffered and waiting.
00347       if (blocks < S_max_blocks)
00348         M_slot_need_more_data();
00349       else
00350       {
00351         Dout(dc::notice, "The buffer is full!");
00352         M_more_data.mutex.lock();
00353         M_buffer_full = true;
00354         // Wake up 'read thread' just in case (special case).
00355         M_more_data.cond.signal();
00356         M_more_data.mutex.unlock();
00357       }
00358     }
00359 
00360     void close(void)
00361     {
00362       M_more_data.mutex.lock();
00363       M_closed = true;
00364       // Wake up 'read thread' just in case (special case).
00365       M_more_data.cond.signal();
00366       M_more_data.mutex.unlock();
00367     }
00368 
00369     bool closed(void) const { return M_closed; }
00370     bool full(void) const { return M_buffer_full; }
00371 
00372     iterator& begin(void)
00373     {
00374       // Wait until there is another block, so we can start to process the first block.
00375       while (!can_process_next_block(M_begin))
00376         wait_for_more_data(M_begin);
00377       return M_begin;
00378     }
00379     iterator end(void) const { return iterator(const_cast<MemoryBlockList*>(this)); }
00380 
00381     //! @brief Return the number of blocks that were appended to the linked list.
00382     int appended_blocks(void) const { return M_appended_blocks; }
00383 
00384     //! Returns ok if the read_thread is allowed to process the block that M_begin is pointing at.
00385     // This function is only called from DatabaseSeekable::read_thread.
00386     bool can_process_next_block(iterator const& iter)
00387     {
00388       // Do not process the last block while we're still writing to the
00389       // buffer because that would require using a mutex on a per character
00390       // basis, while not processing the last block allows us to not us
00391       // locking at all!
00392       return M_closed || M_appended_blocks - iter.processed_blocks() >= 2;
00393     }
00394 
00395     MutexCondPair& more_data(void) { return M_more_data; }
00396 
00397     Glib::Dispatcher& need_more_data(void) { return M_need_more_data; }
00398 
00399     void need_more_data_callback(void);
00400 
00401     void wait_for_more_data(iterator const& iter)
00402     {
00403       Dout(dc::notice, "Waiting for more data...");
00404 continue_waiting:
00405 #if 0
00406       timespec start_sleep_time_real, stop_sleep_time_real;
00407       timespec start_sleep_time_process, stop_sleep_time_process;
00408       clock_gettime(CLOCK_PROCESS_CPUTIME_ID,& start_sleep_time_process);
00409       clock_gettime(CLOCK_REALTIME,& start_sleep_time_real);
00410 #endif
00411       M_more_data.mutex.lock();
00412       if (!M_buffer_full && !M_closed)
00413         M_more_data.cond.wait(M_more_data.mutex);
00414       M_more_data.mutex.unlock();
00415 #if 0
00416       clock_gettime(CLOCK_PROCESS_CPUTIME_ID,& stop_sleep_time_process);
00417       clock_gettime(CLOCK_REALTIME,& stop_sleep_time_real);
00418       stop_sleep_time_process -= start_sleep_time_process;
00419       wait_time_thread_process += stop_sleep_time_process;
00420       stop_sleep_time_real -= start_sleep_time_real;
00421       wait_time_thread_real += stop_sleep_time_real;
00422 #endif
00423       // There is a small possibility that the main thread delayed
00424       // setting M_buffer_full so that this thread already processed
00425       // half of the buffer and got here even before M_buffer_full
00426       // is set. Therefore, this thread is also woken up again
00427       // when M_buffer_full is actually set.
00428       if (M_buffer_full)
00429       {
00430         // Ok that is "weird". Now waste some cpu for this special case.
00431         if (!can_process_next_block(iter))
00432         {
00433           M_need_more_data.emit();
00434           goto continue_waiting;
00435         }
00436       }
00437       Dout(dc::notice, "Got data!");
00438     }
00439 };
